blog.name: sillyfoma
blog.title: hang on, let me get my trainers

body:
today I:

  • slept for 8h 45min!!! and woke up!! so tired!! wtf!!
  • was obviously a bit nutty because i called an uber to come 10 minutes after waking up. so i didn’t have breakfast, pack lunch, wash my face, or do anything except brushing teeth & getting dressed
  • ubered to work (it’s 4mi from home) and had a banana, coffee, 2 bottles of water
  • prawn marie rose (£3 – not bad!) for lunch from the cafeteria closeby
  • work work work
  • bag of tangfastics

feeling:

  • flashes of pain from the period
  • really uncomfortable
  • productive

later:

  • slogged on the bus for an hour – really really regretted not cycling because it’d been so much faster (and cheaper)
  • met up with a friend at a pub, had a pint (bus both ways)
  • went for a walk cos i’d done so little today
  • finished the chickpea/veg/noodle/peanut salad – (surprisingly?) didn’t taste off at all!
  • made a healthyish chocolate mug cake
  • …and had 8 squares of chocolate (40g maybe)?
  • lots of water throughout the day! at least 2L

feeling:

  • felt lots more comfortable w/a tampon rather than a pad + with eyeliner on :)
  • not great and guilty for eating as much chocolate
  • very proud for day 2 without drinking coke :O

going to bed soon. thinking of going for a run first thing in the morning. don’t have any bananas though so idk if i can go on an empty stomach. i’m gonna try and wake up as early as i can (7.30?) so i can do an hour run and have oatmeal AND make it to the library before 10am.

i just…wanna feel like a human again.

summary: Is screen time to blame for dramatic rise in kids with dry eye?
title: Is screen time to blame for dramatic rise in kids with dry eye?
body:
Optometrists have seen a dramatic jump in the number of children suffering from dry eyes and too much screen time could be to blame.

Read more from CTV Health News https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/is-screen-time-to-blame-for-dramatic-rise-in-kids-with-dry-eye-1.4363627

summary: Poliosis (White Hair Patch): Symptoms, Causes And Treatment
title: Poliosis (White Hair Patch): Symptoms, Causes And Treatment
body:
Poliosis is a condition that causes white patches on an individual’s hair. An individual can be born with the condition or can develop it during any point of age. You may have noticed it on some of the famous fictional characters Bellatrix Lestrange from Harry Potter or Benjamin Barker in Sweeney Todd . Individuals with poliosis have a decreased level or complete lack of melanin in their hair follicles.

The condition is also called as poliosis circumscripta and affects your eyelashes, head hair, eyebrows and any other areas with hair. When the condition affects the head hair that is right above the forehead, it is called as white forelock. The white patch can be concentrated in one place or can affect several areas of your hair. In accordance with the underlying causes, the condition can be long-term or short-term , .

[Source: Joe.Miller]

Poliosis is not life-threatening and does not affect your health. However, it can co-occur with some severe medical conditions such as vitiligo, Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease, alopecia areata, sarcoidosis etc.

Symptoms Of Poliosis

It is easy to identify the development of this condition. Signs and symptoms of poliosis include patches of white hair on any part of the body that has hair. Poliosis can appear suddenly at any age, irrespective of gender .

Types Of Poliosis

The condition is categorised into two categories , .

  • Genetic or congenital poliosis: In some cases, poliosis can be hereditary. The white patches of hair can be present at the time of birth due to the mutation of certain genes or other genetic issues.
  • Acquired poliosis: The condition can also develop as a side effect or an after effect of certain medical conditions. It can cause the development of white patches of hair in one’s later stages of life.

Causes Of Poliosis

The reasons for the development of the condition can be pointed out to various reasons. According to common assumptions, poliosis is caused due to psychological trauma, physical shock and stress. Scientifically, it has been proven that the following are the reasons behind the development of poliosis , , .

  • Genetic disorders: Such as piebaldism, Waardenburg’s syndrome, Marfan’s syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) syndrome, giant congenital nevus, and Alezzandrini syndrome.
  • Auto-immune diseases: Such as vitiligo, hypopituitarism, neurofibromatosis, thyroid diseases, sarcoidosis, hypogonadism, idiopathic uveitis, intradermal nevus, post-inflammatory dermatoses, skin cancer, halo nevus, post-trauma, GAPO syndrome, and pernicious anaemia.
  • Other causes: Such as melanoma, alopecia areata, Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome, herpes zoster or shingles, radiotherapy, melanisation defects, dermatitis, albino, injuries, ageing, stress, halo moles, hypo or hyperpigmentation of eyes, leprosy, and certain drugs.

Conditions Associated With Poliosis

As mentioned earlier, it is not life-threatening or harmful. However, it can be an early indication or warning sign of critical health issues . The conditions linked with poliosis are as follows:

  • Melanoma (skin cancer)
  • Uveitis that can lead to glaucoma and cataracts
  • Inflammatory diseases
  • Thyroid disorders that can cause fatigue, trouble swallowing, depression, memory issues, high cholesterol, low sex drive and weight gain

Diagnosis Of Poliosis

The appearance of the grey or white patch of hair is the only sign required to diagnose the condition .

If the condition is affecting your child it is necessary to go to a doctor immediately. Although children can be born with white patches of hair, it can also be an indication of thyroid disorders, vitamin B12 deficiency etc. For this, the doctor may advise a blood test .

However, due to the condition’s association with several other conditions, a thorough check-up may be required. The doctor will go through the medical history of the individual and inquire about the occurrence of poliosis in the family. The diagnosis may include a complete physical inspection,
nutritional survey, endocrinal survey, blood test, analysis of a skin sample and neurological causes .

Treatment For Poliosis

Currently, there is a lack of proper treatment to permanently change the white patches caused by poliosis. However, you can adopt the following measures to limit the onset of the condition .

  • Limited intake of antibiotics
  • Increasing exposure to UV-B lamps
  • Applying Ammi majus medication
  • Undergoing an epidermal grafting on the depigmented skin (present underneath the white hair patch)

Some of the other ways in which the condition can be managed are by dyeing your hair, wearing hats, bandanna, headbands, or other types of hair coverings. Or, you can leave it as it is!

Also Read:

Sleep Drunkenness: Causes, Symptoms And Treatment

Penile Atrophy (Penis Shrinkage): Causes, Treatment And Prevention

World Tuberculosis Day: Ayurvedic Treatment For Pulmonary Tuberculosis

  • Other causes: Such as melanoma, alopecia areata, Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome, herpes zoster or shingles, radiotherapy, melanisation defects, dermatitis, albino, injuries, ageing, stress, halo moles, hypo or hyperpigmentation of eyes, leprosy, and certain drugs.

Conditions Associated With Poliosis

As mentioned earlier, it is not life-threatening or harmful. However, it can be an early indication or warning sign of critical health issues . The conditions linked with poliosis are as follows:

  • Melanoma (skin cancer)
  • Uveitis that can lead to glaucoma and cataracts
  • Inflammatory diseases
  • Thyroid disorders that can cause fatigue, trouble swallowing, depression, memory issues, high cholesterol, low sex drive and weight gain

Diagnosis Of Poliosis

The appearance of the grey or white patch of hair is the only sign required to diagnose the condition .

If the condition is affecting your child it is necessary to go to a doctor immediately. Although children can be born with white patches of hair, it can also be an indication of thyroid disorders, vitamin B12 deficiency etc. For this, the doctor may advise a blood test .

However, due to the condition’s association with several other conditions, a thorough check-up may be required. The doctor will go through the medical history of the individual and inquire about the occurrence of poliosis in the family. The diagnosis may include a complete physical inspection,
nutritional survey, endocrinal survey, blood test, analysis of a skin sample and neurological causes .

Treatment For Poliosis

Currently, there is a lack of proper treatment to permanently change the white patches caused by poliosis. However, you can adopt the following measures to limit the onset of the condition .

  • Limited intake of antibiotics
  • Increasing exposure to UV-B lamps
  • Applying Ammi majus medication
  • Undergoing an epidermal grafting on the depigmented skin (present underneath the white hair patch)

Some of the other ways in which the condition can be managed are by dyeing your hair, wearing hats, bandanna, headbands, or other types of hair coverings. Or, you can leave it as it is!

Also Read:

Sleep Drunkenness: Causes, Symptoms And Treatment

Penile Atrophy (Penis Shrinkage): Causes, Treatment And Prevention

World Tuberculosis Day: Ayurvedic Treatment For Pulmonary Tuberculosis

trail.content_raw:
Poliosis is a condition that causes white patches on an individual’s hair. An individual can be born with the condition or can develop it during any point of age. You may have noticed it on some of the famous fictional characters Bellatrix Lestrange from Harry Potter or Benjamin Barker in Sweeney Todd . Individuals with poliosis have a decreased level or complete lack of melanin in their hair follicles.

The condition is also called as poliosis circumscripta and affects your eyelashes, head hair, eyebrows and any other areas with hair. When the condition affects the head hair that is right above the forehead, it is called as white forelock. The white patch can be concentrated in one place or can affect several areas of your hair. In accordance with the underlying causes, the condition can be long-term or short-term , .

[Source: Joe.Miller]

Poliosis is not life-threatening and does not affect your health. However, it can co-occur with some severe medical conditions such as vitiligo, Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease, alopecia areata, sarcoidosis etc.

Symptoms Of Poliosis

It is easy to identify the development of this condition. Signs and symptoms of poliosis include patches of white hair on any part of the body that has hair. Poliosis can appear suddenly at any age, irrespective of gender .

Types Of Poliosis

The condition is categorised into two categories , .

  • Genetic or congenital poliosis: In some cases, poliosis can be hereditary. The white patches of hair can be present at the time of birth due to the mutation of certain genes or other genetic issues.
  • Acquired poliosis: The condition can also develop as a side effect or an after effect of certain medical conditions. It can cause the development of white patches of hair in one’s later stages of life.

Causes Of Poliosis

The reasons for the development of the condition can be pointed out to various reasons. According to common assumptions, poliosis is caused due to psychological trauma, physical shock and stress. Scientifically, it has been proven that the following are the reasons behind the development of poliosis , , .

  • Genetic disorders: Such as piebaldism, Waardenburg’s syndrome, Marfan’s syndrome, tuberous sclerosis, Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) syndrome, giant congenital nevus, and Alezzandrini syndrome.
  • Auto-immune diseases: Such as vitiligo, hypopituitarism, neurofibromatosis, thyroid diseases, sarcoidosis, hypogonadism, idiopathic uveitis, intradermal nevus, post-inflammatory dermatoses, skin cancer, halo nevus, post-trauma, GAPO syndrome, and pernicious anaemia.
  • Other causes: Such as melanoma, alopecia areata, Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome, herpes zoster or shingles, radiotherapy, melanisation defects, dermatitis, albino, injuries, ageing, stress, halo moles, hypo or hyperpigmentation of eyes, leprosy, and certain drugs.

Conditions Associated With Poliosis

As mentioned earlier, it is not life-threatening or harmful. However, it can be an early indication or warning sign of critical health issues . The conditions linked with poliosis are as follows:

  • Melanoma (skin cancer)
  • Uveitis that can lead to glaucoma and cataracts
  • Inflammatory diseases
  • Thyroid disorders that can cause fatigue, trouble swallowing, depression, memory issues, high cholesterol, low sex drive and weight gain

Diagnosis Of Poliosis

The appearance of the grey or white patch of hair is the only sign required to diagnose the condition .

If the condition is affecting your child it is necessary to go to a doctor immediately. Although children can be born with white patches of hair, it can also be an indication of thyroid disorders, vitamin B12 deficiency etc. For this, the doctor may advise a blood test .

However, due to the condition’s association with several other conditions, a thorough check-up may be required. The doctor will go through the medical history of the individual and inquire about the occurrence of poliosis in the family. The diagnosis may include a complete physical inspection,
nutritional survey, endocrinal survey, blood test, analysis of a skin sample and neurological causes .

Treatment For Poliosis

Currently, there is a lack of proper treatment to permanently change the white patches caused by poliosis. However, you can adopt the following measures to limit the onset of the condition .

  • Limited intake of antibiotics
  • Increasing exposure to UV-B lamps
  • Applying Ammi majus medication
  • Undergoing an epidermal grafting on the depigmented skin (present underneath the white hair patch)

Some of the other ways in which the condition can be managed are by dyeing your hair, wearing hats, bandanna, headbands, or other types of hair coverings. Or, you can leave it as it is!

Also Read:

Sleep Drunkenness: Causes, Symptoms And Treatment

summary: U.S. investigates seizure risk with electronic cigarettes
title: U.S. investigates seizure risk with electronic cigarettes
body:
U.S. health officials are investigating whether electronic cigarettes may trigger seizures in some people who use the nicotine-vaping devices.

Read more from CTV Health News https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/u-s-investigates-seizure-risk-with-electronic-cigarettes-1.4363629

summary: Roman soldier graffiti phallus comes to light Archaeologists documenting graffiti carved by Roman soldiers near Hadrian’s Wall...
caption: Roman soldier graffiti phallus comes to light Archaeologists documenting graffiti carved by Roman soldiers near Hadrian’s Wall in the 3rd century uncovered a large phallus concealed for centuries behind vegetation. Soldiers left their distinctive marks in 207 A.D.

summary: 4 Reasons Why the Alliance of American Football (AAF) is Suspending Operations https://ift.tt/eA8V8J
title: 4 Reasons Why the Alliance of American Football (AAF) is Suspending Operations https://ift.tt/eA8V8J
description:
The rumors had been floating around for the last couple of weeks, but on Tuesday it was official. The Alliance of American Football (AAF) has officially suspended operations. This decision was made by AAF chairman Tom Dundon, although co-founder Bill Polian has voiced opposition to this move, leaving the league’s future in doubt.
Read the full story on Athlon Sports

summary: Psychostimulants play a major role in fatal strokes among young adults
title: Psychostimulants play a major role in fatal strokes among young adults
body:
Investigators found that from 2009-2016, psychostimulant users constituted nearly a fifth of the 279 cases of fatal stroke in adults aged 15-44 years, the majority of which had evidence of consumption immediately prior to the fatal stroke. Methamphetamine was overwhelmingly the drug implicated…. eCommerce web development

https://russia.timesofnews.com/psychostimulants-play-a-major-role-in-fatal-strokes-among-young-adults/
